Joe Gillis.Action: Narrates his struggles openly, acknowledging his lack of success and lost touch.
Refuses to give car keys to the men demanding the car, challenges their authority.
Calmly tries to defuse tension by joking ('Relax, fans. The car isn't here.') and attempts to reassure the men with a plausible story about the car.
Lies about the whereabouts of the car to avoid immediate trouble with the finance company.
Momentarily ponders the situation alone, showing internal awareness but no direct engagement or confrontation.
Calmly negotiates with finance men despite being behind on payments, attempts to use humor and diversion to ease tension.
Deceives finance men by claiming the car is lent to a friend in Palm Springs and inviting them to check the garage, though it is not there.
Internally admits he needed money quickly, but is caught in his own lie as car is neither in Palm Springs nor garage.
Carelessly drops car keys with identifying charms when bending to pick them up, potentially revealing his deception.
Keeps his car parked a couple of blocks away behind Rudy's Shoeshine Parlor to avoid attention; Rudy never asks questions and winks after him.
Keeps to himself and moves cautiously around the studio area, avoiding drawing attention.
Presents a story concept clearly and professionally to Sheldrake, showing cooperation and straightforwardness.
Presents a clear, concise story pitch quickly within five minutes, showing preparation and an understanding of the need to be persuasive.
Has developed a 40-page outline and a catchy title 'Bases Loaded' to accompany his pitch, demonstrating preparedness and organization.
Expresses opinion dismissively about another executive (Zanuck) being 'all wet', suggesting confidence but potentially risking politeness or diplomacy.
Offers help to Betty Schaefer despite her criticism of his script.
Stands silently near the door while Betty places papers, showing passive reception.
Proposes a detailed, practical plan for a film project including casting, shooting style, and budget, showing an understanding of industry needs and constraints.
Responds calmly and politely to criticism from Betty Schaefer about his script, indicating professional composure but no immediate defense or improvement plan.
Responds to criticism about his work with sarcasm and dismissiveness.
Acknowledges his need for a job honestly and plainly.
Engages in playful banter with Mr. Sheldrake, despite stress.
Engages in witty, sharp dialogue while negotiating the artistic qualities and commercial aspects of a screenplay, showing awareness of industry expectations.
Admits he is trying to earn a living rather than produce serious art, demonstrating pragmatic self-awareness.
Recognizes the commercial limitations of the project, openly stating he doesn’t expect an Academy Award, showing practical realism.
Responds sarcastically and with humor when under pressure, indicating both confidence and a defensive attitude.
Does not push back aggressively or attempt to strongly influence Betty or Sheldrake, potentially showing a lack of assertiveness in protecting his creative vision.
Directly asks Sheldrake for a personal loan despite being rejected for work; tries to secure immediate financial help due to urgent need.
Realizes the hopelessness of his situation and leaves the meeting promptly after rejection.
Sits at Schwab's Drug Store sending out a general S.O.S. with ten nickels, indicating resourcefulness in seeking connections or help.
Demonstrates frustration and desperation but continues to try avenues for work.
Tries persistently to find work and contacts friends and agents despite repeated refusals.
Calls his own agent a 'big faker' and curses him for not helping.
Pulls down the sunshade to hide his face from pursuers.
Drives recklessly to escape pursuers, narrowly avoiding accidents, and ends up in a run-down mansion driveway.
Carefully pilots the limping vehicle into the garage and surveys the neglected surroundings with idle curiosity.
Carefully pilots the limping vehicle into one of the garage stalls and closes the door.
Mounts the staircase out of idle curiosity and surveys the surroundings cautiously.
Formulates a plan to hide out at Artie Green’s and eventually escape to Ohio to avoid pursuit by creditors.
Abandons his apartment hastily as 'bloodhounds' are on to him, showing some pressure but also an ability to adapt quickly.
Responds compliantly to Max's reminders and follows Norma's instructions without complaint.
Shows morbid fascination with the bizarre surroundings but maintains composure, indicating tolerance toward unusual situations.
Complies quickly and without resistance when Max gestures him to go upstairs despite his initial wish to speak, showing some passivity but readiness to adapt.

Shows morbid fascination and hesitation when climbing the grand staircase, stopping undecided at the top before following the woman's voice, indicating some uncertainty and lack of confident decisiveness.
Sympathetically acknowledges Norma's loss and expresses regret.
Reacts with slight recoil to the dead chimpanzee arm but stays composed.
Politely refuses to inflate the price despite Norma's wealth.
Attempts to explain his presence calmly without confrontation.
Ultimately asked to leave and complies without argument.
Stares and recoils at the sight of the dead chimpanzee's arm.
Tries to keep calm and justifies his presence with an excuse about a flat tire and the garage.
Politely tries to dissuade Norma from choosing red as a coffin lining color, showing some tact.
Appears uncertain and easily intimidated when Norma orders him to leave.
Acknowledges Norma's fame with some irony but does not mock harshly, tries to keep a light tone in conversation.
Jokes about bringing an autograph album or cement for footprints, showing a teasing but somewhat dismissive attitude.
Responds calmly and somewhat gently to Norma's frustration rather than escalating the conflict.
Recognizes Norma Desmond and references her past fame, showing cultural knowledge and awareness.
Uses humor and sarcasm in conversation with Norma (popcorn business, monkey remark), displaying wit and social confidence.
Acknowledges his lower status as a writer compared to executives, showing realistic self-awareness.
Leaves Norma's presence after being told to get out, showing he knows when to disengage and avoid escalating conflict.
Makes a sarcastic remark about bringing an autograph album or cement for footprints, using humor even in a tense situation.
Replies to Norma's questioning with light sarcasm but continues engaging her with humor.
Responds to Norma's curiosity and follows her into the living room without resistance.
Engages in conversation with Norma, listens to her passionately describe her project without mocking or dismissing her.
Warns Norma about the risk of letting others read her script to prevent theft, showing concern.
Responds with a sarcastic remark 'They'll love it in Pomona,' potentially dismissive but said in a neutral tone.
Evaluates Norma's script volume realistically, showing awareness of screenplay length and practical output.
Responds to Norma's ambitious project with neutral skepticism and mild sarcasm ("They'll love it in Pomona."), indicating some critical perspective.
Advises Norma not to let another writer read her work for fear of theft, showing cautiousness and professional know-how.
Mentions 'twenty-twenty vision' when asked about lighting, indicating light humor and confidence in himself.
Shows hesitation and uncertainty at Norma's command to sit, with a slow 'Well....', possibly indicating reluctance or discomfort.
Observes and critically reflects on the quality of Norma's writing, showing insight and a level of critical thinking.
Notes and interprets the dynamics of the people around him, including Max's role and Norma's behavior, demonstrating situational awareness.
Passive and somewhat detached, allowing others to dictate the environment (like Norma forcing him more script), showing lack of assertiveness.
Tries to gently suggest improvements to Norma's script while acknowledging her passion and effort.
Uses somewhat sarcastic remarks ('silly hodgepodge of melodramatic plots') and mildly patronizing comments about Norma not being a professional.
Critically reads Norma's script and offers constructive feedback about its length, repetition, dialogue, and organization.
Maintains a polite, somewhat restrained demeanor while addressing Norma's emotional investment in her writing.
Appears somewhat resigned or tired (feeling sick at stomach), suggesting possible stress or hesitation.
Politely responds to Norma, thanks her for trust comment.
Declines Norma's offer to do work due to busy schedule.
Mentions his high pay rate when negotiating work.
Attempts to politely postpone work by suggesting taking script home.
Accepts Norma's offer to stay despite initially declining, showing some trust.
Thanks Max politely for preparing the room and supplies.
Comments wryly about the shabby room rather than complaining.
Engages in casual conversation about Norma Desmond with some interest.
Feels pleased with handling the situation by cleverly dropping the hook so his car would be safe, enabling him to focus on fixing the script and earning money.
Accepts the poor room without complaint, making the best of a bad situation.
Shows a detached, somewhat cynical observation of decay and loss at the Desmond estate.
Attends respectfully to Max by looking after him and hanging his coat over a chair.
Observes funeral ritual for the chimp with a reflective, somewhat compassionate voiceover, wondering about the emptiness of Norma's life.
Moves a heavy chair to block the door after noticing the lock has been gouged out, then retreats to read manuscripts quietly alone.
Notices strange scene below, reflecting thoughtfully on Norma and the situation.
Locks door by moving a heavy chair in front rather than finding a key.
Throws himself on bed and casually picks up manuscript pages to read despite unsettling atmosphere.
Observes the changed room with belongings arranged, shows a quiet acceptance and adjustment.
Startled by the arrangement but does not react negatively or suspiciously, indicating tolerance and calmness.
Storms into the room angrily demanding to know why his things are moved without permission.
Refuses Norma's help and insists on paying his own bills despite financial trouble.
Engages in a sharp and somewhat confrontational dialogue with Max and Norma.
Agrees to let Norma unpack his things despite wanting to leave quickly; works diligently on the manuscript despite Norma's constant hovering.
Cuts out a scene from Norma's script that depicts her going to the slave market, showing blunt honesty but potentially insensitivity.
Accepts Norma's financial support with a practical attitude and tries to negotiate salary deduction, showing pragmatism.
Initially resists unpacking but eventually allows it to happen for practical reasons, showing adaptability.
Works hard on the manuscript, actively editing Norma's disorganized script by cutting unnecessary scenes, demonstrating editorial skill and determination.
Feels pressured and distracted by Norma's constant hovering, which affects his ability to fully focus and work efficiently.
Resignedly accepts Norma's delusions without confrontation, thinks of her gently as a sleepwalker.
Cuts a scene because it's 'old hat' and dismisses Norma's continuing fan mail cynically.
Recognizes the futility of arguing with Norma, choosing instead to avoid conflict to maintain peace.
Resignedly accepts Norma's fantasies without confrontation, showing an understanding of her mental state.
Cuts out an old scene from the script that would not work, showing awareness of audience preferences.
Does not challenge Norma's inflated self-image despite recognizing its irrationality.
Allows Norma to hold his arm tightly despite discomfort, but gently withdraws and leans away to discourage further closeness.
Remains silent and passive while sitting closely with Norma, showing tolerance but limited warmth.
Does not like Norma holding his arm but tactfully withdraws and leans away, crossing his arms to discourage further physical closeness, showing controlled and subtle communication of his boundaries.
Observes Norma closely and notes her behavior and feelings, showing attentiveness and situational awareness.
Does not act on discomfort when Norma holds his arm tightly, appears somewhat passive or resigned to her behavior.
Gently withdraws his arm and leans away to discourage Norma's approach, maintaining a measured distance.
Kibitzes on a boring card game without enthusiasm, showing disengagement from social interaction.
Attempts to avoid people who came for his car by hiding and denying presence.
Dumps cigarette butts awkwardly into the cold fireplace and tries to speak privately to Norma about urgent money needs.
Persistently tries to get Norma's attention to ask for money despite her being focused on the card game, showing need but limited interpersonal tact.
Turns away frustrated and embarrassed by social scrutiny and leaves in discomfort.
Quickly notices his lost car and promptly comes out to assess the situation, showing situational awareness.
Expresses frustration and embarrassment but does not seem to take assertive action to resolve the car problem immediately.
Takes a ghostwriting job to solve his financial issues, showing practical decision-making and adaptability.
Allows Norma to overshadow his concerns and decisions (e.g., about the cars), which may indicate passivity or lack of confidence.
Sits uncomfortably beside Norma and initially resists changing his appearance to suit her demands, showing some hesitation and lack of confidence in his own presentation.
Eventually goes along with Norma's plans to improve his wardrobe and appearance, cooperating with salesmen and the tailor despite his reluctance, indicating some adaptability.
Questions Norma about the need for clothing changes, showing a measure of practical judgement about his own needs, but also a certain passivity under her control.
Accepts the camel's hair coat rather than the more expensive Vicuna, showing practicality and consideration for expenses.
Surveys and collects his belongings thoughtfully before leaving the room over the garage, indicating a sense of responsibility and care.
Expresses dislike for moving to the main house but accepts it for practical reasons, showing tolerance and adaptability.
Throws slippers at the foot of the bed, appears slightly embarrassed when told about the room's history, pauses thoughtfully at window.
Questions about missing locks on doors, shows concern by noticing details about the house and its occupant's state.
Reflects on Norma Desmond's faded glory with sympathy calling her a 'poor devil', acknowledges her pride despite her lost fame.
Appears uneasy and self-conscious at Norma's New Year's party, sensing her feelings toward him.
Makes a slow 360-degree turn when Norma asks him to, showing a willingness to humor and engage with her.
Remarks self-deprecatingly about his physique ('All padding. Don't let it fool you.'), showing modesty and a lack of pretension.
Questions whether they should wait for others before drinking, indicating some degree of consideration and social awareness.
Responds to Norma's flamboyant gestures and suggestions with light humor but no signs of irritation or dismissal.
Engages playfully in a private, intimate tango with Norma, showing attentiveness to her dance posture and humor during the moment.
Expresses mild impatience and checks the time, concerned about other guests arriving, showing some doubt about the exclusivity of the night.
Jokes about disruptive behavior ('blindfolding the orchestra and smashing champagne glasses on Max's head'), indicating a playful but somewhat irreverent attitude.
Glances at his wristwatch and inquires about the arrival time of guests, showing attention to detail and time management.
Makes light, witty remarks about the situation (e.g., suggesting blindfolding the orchestra), indicating cleverness and social confidence.
Focuses on enjoying the moment and engaging in playful banter with Norma, demonstrating social ease but no particular strategic action.
Refuses Norma's expensive gift, expresses discomfort with her taking him for granted, and asserts his desire for independence.
Dismisses Norma's expressions of love harshly and avoids confronting her feelings directly.
Does not respond to Norma's accusation about not wanting her love, leading to tension and emotional hurt.
Refuses Norma's expensive gifts, attempts to assert his independence and personal boundaries by expressing discomfort with her control and wealth.
Fails to effectively communicate his feelings and desires, leading to a tense, unresolved confrontation and his subsequent paralysis after being slapped.
Glances furtively to see if his humiliation has been observed after being slapped.
Attempts to mask embarrassment by yanking his keychain loose and walking with nonchalance.
Narrates his need to leave, expressing desire to be with people his own age and to hear laughter again.
Successfully hails a ride by jumping into a florist's delivery wagon after failing to get a regular ride.
Arrives at a modest, crowded party casually and engages with acquaintances coolly and confidently.
Passively allows himself to be teased about dubious rumors (e.g., opium smuggler, Black Dahlia suspect) without assertive response.
Greets some of the kids by name as he and Artie enter the room.
Embarrassed as Artie takes his coat and jokes about it.
Engages amicably with Artie, humor and casual conversation at the party.
Requests to stay with Artie and accepts hospitality.
Engages in a candid conversation with Betty about his writing, listens to her feedback without dismissiveness.
Uses somewhat cynical or defensive remarks about writing (e.g., 'Who wants true? Who wants moving?').
Invites Betty to the Rainbow Room to talk privately, indicating a willingness to engage meaningfully.
Suggests they live it up on New Year's Eve despite the serious conversation, showing a playful and friendly side.
Politely acknowledges criticism of his work and discusses it with Betty, showing awareness and willingness to engage about his writing.
Dismisses the value of truth and emotional depth in fiction with a cynical comment: 'Who wants true? Who wants moving?'
Suggests going out to celebrate New Year's Eve instead of focusing on writing ideas, showing a tendency to avoid serious work.
Suggests capturing the kitchen and barricading the door to gain tactical advantage.
Makes flirtatious and distracted remarks ignoring the phone call.
Quickly takes the opportunity to use the phone to call Max and arrange retrieval of belongings despite interruptions.
Stands numb with shock upon hearing about a suicide attempt, pushes Betty aside without a word.
Rushes toward the door immediately to help after learning someone self-harmed.
Ignores Betty's attempt at lightheartedness in a serious moment, spilling the drink she carries.
Questions Max about Norma’s condition and proceeds carefully into the house despite urgency.
Immediately reacts with shock to the crisis but promptly pushes past distractions to leave and meet the doctor, showing situational awareness and urgency.
Pushes Betty aside, spilling her drink, and quickly secures a coat and runs out, demonstrating quick decision-making under pressure.
Rushes to the Desmond house and insists on knowing Norma's condition, showing initiative and concern.
Ignores Max's warning and pushes past him, risking upsetting the musicians who are unaware of the situation, indicating potential impulsiveness or disregard for careful planning.
Carefully removes Norma's shoes and places them gently on the floor.
Engages in a tender but awkward conversation, expressing he didn't want to hurt Norma and acknowledging she has been good to him.
Uses sarcasm about the potential headlines involving Norma's suicide.
Stands looking at Norma helplessly, showing emotional concern without knowing how to respond.
Refuses to leave until Norma promises to act sensibly, showing a desire to help her despite tension.
Comforts Norma while she is sobbing, gently puts his arms on her shoulders and turns her around, repeats sincere 'Happy New Year' wishes
Engages casually with Norma in the pool and banters about the astrology and script, showing a relaxed and somewhat humorous demeanor.
Questions Norma’s reliance on astrology for selling the script, showing a pragmatic attitude but not dismissive or harsh.
Questions the logic of sending a script based on an astrologer's chart, showing some practical skepticism.
Passively accepts Norma's plan to deliver the script personally despite doubting its merit, lacking assertiveness to challenge or redirect her.
Offers Norma one of his own cigarettes when hers are empty, then takes initiative to get her some from the drugstore.
Responds helpfully and attentively to Norma's needs, showing consideration and care.
Recognizes Norma forgot her cigarettes and offers his own despite knowing she dislikes them.
Politely asks to stop at the drugstore to get cigarettes for Norma, showing initiative and attentiveness.
Hurries into the drugstore and confidently orders a specific brand of cigarettes.
Greets Artie and Betty politely; engages in friendly conversation despite prior absence.
Makes a sarcastic comment about the script being made into a lampshade.
Admits to not keeping himself anywhere lately, implying vulnerability.
Engages in casual banter but seems unaware or uninformed about the industry news and opportunities Betty brings, showing some disengagement and lack of proactive effort.
Responds skeptically and humorously to Betty's enthusiasm, indicating a wary, somewhat guarded attitude rather than confident acceptance.
Accepts the potential opportunity presented by Betty but without evident enthusiasm or initiative, showing passive rather than active behavior in advancing his career.
Politely declines Betty's offer to collaborate on a story, expressing his decision to stop writing.
Thanks others for their interest in his career before leaving.
Quickly leaves the conversation despite Betty's visible frustration and desire to work together.
Refuses to engage deeply with Betty's story ideas and gives up on writing altogether, indicating a lack of confidence and commitment.
Politely exits the meeting despite the tension, showing awareness and control of the situation.
Quickly adapts to Max's call and leaves promptly, suggesting punctuality and responsiveness.
Realizes he forgot Norma's cigarettes and returns her dollar.
Tells Norma she is smoking too much, showing concern.
Lolls on a couch watching Norma's playful performance, appearing very bored.
Responds to Norma's question about his mood with sarcasm and feigned enthusiasm.
Forgets Norma's cigarettes but immediately notices and returns the dollar to her.
Warns Norma that she is smoking too much, demonstrating some awareness and concern.
Lolls bored on a couch, showing disengagement and lack of active participation.
Responds ironically to Norma’s performance, hiding his true feelings to maintain social charm.
Thinks empathetically about the struggles and ambitions of a young writer trying to succeed in Hollywood.
Lets Norma dominate the conversation and does not assert his own opinions or feelings.
Thinks critically about the nature of Hollywood screenwriters and shows understanding of the industry's realities.
Responds skeptically to Norma's excitement about a call from Paramount; demonstrates grounded perspective.
Fails to correct Norma's mistaken assumption that Mr. deMille is personally calling; does not challenge her delusion explicitly.
Speaks with pride about Norma's moment, showing patience and respect for her timing.
Sits quietly beside Norma while she prepares herself, not interrupting or belittling her.
Firmly refuses to lower Norma's price despite pressure, showing self-respect and negotiation skill.
Sits beside Norma in the limousine quietly while she prepares and makes decisions, showing passive support but not taking control.
Fails to get Norma a direct appointment with deMille, despite arrival at studio, relying on Norma's attempts to proceed, indicating limited influence or planning.
Notices the 'Readers' Department' sign and chooses to approach it, implying awareness of an opportunity.
Offers Betty to use his novel for free, showing generosity but also possibly pragmatic detachment from his own work.
Engages in light negotiation about chocolate creams, suggesting casual confidence in social interactions but no significant professional assertiveness.
Dismisses Betty's story ideas quickly, stating he doesn't have time to listen to the whole plot.
Acknowledges Betty's efforts but declines to collaborate on her script, citing being 'all tied up' and impossible to work together.
Responds to Betty's engagement news with a polite compliment to her fiancé.
Encourages Betty to write the story despite difficulties, suggesting creative plot ideas confidently and showing insight into storytelling.
Quickly leaves when confronted, avoiding commitment or involvement in Betty's writing process.
Shows apprehension but engages politely with Norma and Max during the car ride, exchanging glances and discussing the situation calmly.
Apprehensively asks Norma how the meeting with DeMille went, showing awareness of the stakes.
Exchanges meaningful glances with Max and Norma, demonstrating attentiveness to social cues and the situation.
Does not intervene or offer concrete suggestions during the discussion of the movie deal, displaying some passivity.
Lies fully clothed, reading a book quietly and calmly when Norma enters, responding briefly and maintaining composure.
Responds to Norma's anxious and self-conscious remarks with minimal engagement and monotone replies, showing a lack of emotional support or deeper engagement.
Admits to driving to the beach instead of telling the truth initially; tries to explain his need for freedom but shows some sensitivity to Norma's feelings.
Listens to Norma's worries and acknowledges her need for patience and kindness but responds defensively.
Puts down his book and looks at Norma's door after she says goodnight, suggesting some emotional attention.
Silently leaves Norma's house late at night, trying not to be noticed.
Reflects on childhood memories about sneaking out to see gangster pictures, shows a degree of nostalgia and vulnerability.
Works cooperatively with Betty Schaefer late at night, discussing writing and accepting her suggestion to have coffee.
Silently descends stairs and exits quietly in moonlight, showing care to avoid detection.
Drives the car out as quietly as possible, indicating cautiousness and control.
Paces and discusses sentence construction with Betty Schafer, engaging seriously with his writing work.
Agrees to have coffee with Betty and engages in light conversation, showing openness and friendly interaction.
Sincerely expresses happiness in writing again and acknowledges self-doubt openly.
Downplays the inscription 'MAD ABOUT THE BOY -- Norma' as coming from a foolish but generous friend, showing some protective or discreet attitude.
Agreeing to Betty's suggestion and immediately resuming typing, showing focus and willingness to engage in work.
Assessing the dialogue as good and workable, indicating discernment and professional judgment.
Enjoying writing again and expressing happiness about it, showing confidence and renewed motivation.
Avoiding directly explaining 'Norma' when asked, providing a vague and dismissive answer.
Engages in a friendly walk and casual conversation with Betty, showing interest in her background.
Dismisses Betty's comment with a slightly sarcastic remark about plot familiarity and asks her to proofread a script.
Gives Betty advice on an idiotic script.
Dismisses readers by sarcastically suggesting they proof-read page ten while the water boils instead of listening.
Engages in thoughtful observation and conversation while walking the studio lot, showing familiarity and reflection on the filmmaking environment.
Lightly teases Betty about her past ambitions, then praises her current job and affectionately kisses her nose.
Makes playful, sincere compliments about Betty's scent and youth, showing affection and friendliness.
Suggests keeping physical distance to focus on work, balancing affection with professionalism.
Understands the realities of the film industry and realistically assesses Betty's career and ambitions, showing insight.
Engages in playful banter and flirtation smoothly, demonstrating social confidence and ease.
Jokes about serious matters like Betty's nose surgery but remains supportive, indicating emotional intelligence and tact.
Engages in sarcastic banter with Max, showing skepticism about feeding Madame lies.
Shows concern about the consequences of deceiving Norma.
Folds a batch of script and puts it in his pocket, shows awareness of being watched and reacts with a witty retort to Max's spying.
Admits to writing a script and expresses strong determination to finish it despite difficulties.
Engages in a sharp conversation with Max, demonstrating quick wit and understanding of the situation regarding feeding lies to Norma.
Shows skepticism and insight about Max's role and Norma's condition, reflecting perceptiveness.
Sits with Betty, tries to engage her and coax her to open up about what's wrong.
Keeps the script co-written with Betty hidden in his coat pocket, not openly sharing it with Norma who is anxious and suspicious.
Carries a script with him and is actively involved in writing (author credit shown on script).
Is asleep when Norma comes to confront him, showing no immediate reaction or awareness.
Interacts with Betty professionally and shows social awareness by noticing her mood and attempting to engage her.
Does not prevent Norma's discovery of the script that reveals his collaboration with Betty; an omission that leads to conflict.
Comforts Betty when she is crying, encourages her to stop crying and be positive about her marriage
Presses Betty about her feelings and what happened between her and Artie
Takes Betty in his arms after she admits she is not in love with Artie but with him
Encourages Betty to face her emotional situation and finish the script on time, demonstrating practical focus and support.
Sinks down on chaise longue thinking, reflecting on complex personal and professional situations, showing thoughtful insight.
Takes Betty in his arms after her admission, demonstrating emotional responsiveness but possibly blurring professional boundaries.
Acknowledges he was a 'heel' and regrets not being truthful with Norma about his feelings.
Thinks about escaping the 'nasty mess' in his life rather than confronting it honestly.
Thinks carefully and plans to get away from his difficult situation with Norma, hoping to change his life.
Does not reveal the truth to Norma about his feelings and the realities of their relationship, indicating emotional avoidance and dishonesty.
Calmly takes the telephone receiver from Norma, asserts himself by speaking into the phone to Betty, inviting her to see his living situation for herself.
Calmly takes the phone receiver from Norma and addresses Betty directly, asserting control over the situation.
Suggests Betty come over and see for herself rather than continuing the confrontation by phone.
Sits motionless in a corner while Norma repeats her pleas and shows emotional distress, then leaves the room silently when the doorbell rings.
Expresses a desire to hear the doorbell instead of engaging emotionally with Norma's distress.
Greets Betty warmly at the door and puts his arm around her shoulders as he leads her inside.
Jokes lightly about the house's history and amenities, tries to make Betty feel comfortable.
Refers to Norma Desmond's jealousy dismissively, calling her 'junk' and mocking the house decor.
Describes Norma Desmond's house and situation somewhat cynically, highlighting his own material possessions over emotional connection.
Dismisses Betty's emotional plea and prioritizes his own practical and financial interests over her feelings.
Leads Betty to the door after the argument, showing a reluctant but courteous action to escort her out.
Clearly explains the wealthy household setup and his role in it to Betty, showing awareness and communicative ability.
Reluctantly chooses comfort and security of a long-term, low-risk contract over uncertainty, showing practical decision-making.
Dismisses Betty's emotional appeal and offers a cynical, self-interested perspective, revealing limited emotional intelligence but clear pragmatism.
Hesitates or delays taking decisive action to leave the comfortable but unfulfilling situation, suggesting fear or complacency.
Wishes Betty good luck warmly, invites her to the pool when she returns.
Does not stop for Norma's affectionate gesture and moves straight into his room, ignoring her.
Opens the door for Betty and wishes her good luck, showing politeness and calm control over the situation.
Switches on the pool light after opening the door, indicating attentiveness to detail and maintaining environment.
Closes the door after Betty leaves and looks up upon hearing sobbing, showing situational awareness and emotional sensitivity.
Ascends the stairs toward Norma after hearing her sobbing, indicating a willingness to confront emotional situations.
Avoids letting Norma kiss his hand and moves directly into his room despite her attempts to engage affectionately, demonstrating emotional restraint but possibly a social awkwardness or coldness.
Tells Norma hard truths about her fading stardom and tries to get her to face reality.
Calmly removes cuff-links Norma gave him before confronting her.
Calmly closes the suitcase and removes cuff-links, demonstrating composure.
Confronts Norma with harsh realities about her fading stardom in a straightforward, logical manner.
Encourages Max to confirm the truth to Norma, pushing for realistic acceptance.
Dismisses Norma's denial and wishful thinking effectively, showing clear perception.
Shows empathy balanced with blunt honesty, trying to make Norma face reality without cruelty.
Interaction reveals that despite the sensitivity of topic, he maintains control and clarity.
Leaves Norma despite her pleas and threats, carrying the typewriter, does not show hesitance or remorse while departing.
Does not look back or engage with Norma after hearing gunshots, continues leaving calmly.
No direct action or involvement in the scene; mostly observers like Max and Norma in focus.
